concept.title: Alarm Creation
concept.shortdesc: This page allows you to define alarms that are useful in generating notifications and metrics required by your organization. By default, alarm definitions are sorted by name and in a table format.

section.title: Search and Sort
section.p: The search bar allows you to filter the alarm definitions you want to view. Type and Status are examples of alarm criteria that can be specified. Additionally, you can filter by typing in text similar to searching by keywords.
The checkbox allows you to select (or deselect) a group of alarm definitions to delete:

ul.li: Select Visible allows you to delete the selected alarm definitions from the table.
Select All allows you to delete all the alarms from the table.
Clear Selection allows you to clear all the selections currently selected from the table.

section.p: You can display the alarm definitions by grid, list or table views by selecting the corresponding icons next to the Sort By control.
The Sort By control contains a drop-down list of ways by which you can sort the alarm definitions. Alternatively, you can also sort using the column headers in the table.

ul.li: Sort by Name displays the alarm definitions by the name assigned to it when it was created.
Sort by Description displays the descriptive details of the alarm definitions.
Sort by Notifications Enabled displays the alarm definitions' notification criteria, such as whether enabled for certain types of alarms and how the notification is disseminated (by Email, Web, etc.)

section.title: Create Alarm Definitions
section.p: The Create Alarm Definition button beside the search bar allows you to create a new alarm definition.
To create a new alarm definition:

ol.li: Click the Create Alarm Definitions button to open a separate window that allows you to configure a new alarm.

In the Create Alarm Definition window, type a name for the alarm in the Name text field. The name is required and may be up to 255 characters in length consisting of letters, numbers, or special characters.
Provide some useful details about the alarm in the Description text field (optional).

Set the severity level for the alarm in the Severity drop-down menu. The severity level is optional but subjective, so choose the level appropriate for prioritizing the handling of alarms when they occur.

Although not required, in order to specify how to receive notifications, you must be able to select the method(s) of notification (Email, Web, API, etc.) from the list of options in the Alarm Notifications area. If none are available to choose from, you must first configure them in the Notifications Methods window. Refer to the Notification Methods help page for further instructions.
To turn the notifications on for the alarm, click to select Enable Notifications.

Apply the following rules to your alarm by using the Alarm Expressions form:
Function: determines the output value from a supplied input value.
Metric: applies a pre-defined means of measuring whatever aspect of the alarm.
Relational Operator: specifies the operator for how you want the alarm to trigger.
Value: determines the numeric threshold associated with the operator you specified.
Dimensions: identifies which aspect (Hostname, Region, and Service) of the alarm you want to monitor.
Select whether you want to apply the expressions individually or as a group to the previously selected dimension(s).
When done creating the alarm, click Create Alarm. If you want to create multiple expressions for the alarm, or use the Alarm Expression Editor instead, proceed to the next section.

section.title: Alarm Expression Editor
section.p: The Alarm Expression Editor is particularly useful if you already know the string syntax of the expression(s) you want to use, or can paste it from another expression and adjust values in the syntax as needed.
If you prefer to use an Expression Editor instead, perform the following steps:

ol.li:
Click the Convert to Alarm Expression Editor button.
The right half of the form turns into a free-form text field.
Type or paste syntax for the expression you want to use. Adjust values as necessary.

Once in the Editor mode, and you need to create a new expression, click the Alarm Expression Editor button to open the Alarm Expressions form. The form on this screen allows you to set up one or multiple expressions at once. For more information about working with multiple expressions, refer to the next section.
Use the form to apply rules to your alarm as described in the Create Alarm Definitions section.
When done applying rules to create an expression for your alarm, click Create Alarm.

section.title: Work with Multiple Expressions
section.p: You may create, edit, or delete multiple expressions using the Alarm Expression Editor form.

ol.li: From the Create Alarm Definition window, click the Convert to Alarm Expression Editor button if not already converted.
Click the Alarm Expression Editor button to open a separate window.
Use the form to apply rules to your alarm as described in the Create Alarm Definitions section.

Click Add New Expression to add another expression to your alarm.
A new blank form is inserted for creating a new expression.
Repeat for each new expression you want to add.

If there are multiple expressions, the following options are available:
To edit an expression, locate the one you want to edit, change its values and then click the Update Expression button.
To remove any expression you no longer need, locate the expression you want to delete, and click the Delete Expression button.
To create expressions to be included as part of a group, click the Add New Expression Group button, then refer to the previous section to create multiple expressions for each group.
To add more expression groups, click the Add New Expression Group button to insert a new Expression Group form.
To remove any expression group you no longer need, locate the expression group you want to delete, and click the Delete Expression Group button.
Specify the type of trigger you want for each expression group by selecting Any Expression in Group to let the alarm trigger if the criteria applied to any of the expressions in the group is met; or select All Expressions in the Group to only trigger the alarm if all the critera of all the expressions in the group are met.

Multiple group expressions must have triggering conditions, which is presented in a table format at the bottom of the form in the Expression Group Combination Triggering Conditions area:
You may set Any, All or None of the groups to trigger by selecting the conditions and their associated expession groups.
When done specifying the triggers and their conditions, click the Set Conditions button.
To see the syntax of the newly created expressions, click the View Expressions Syntax button.
Viewing the syntax opens a window showing the entire expression(s) created, like in the following example:avg(cpu.system_perc{hostname=hostname.domain.com}) > 90 or avg(disk_read_ops{hostname=hostname.domain.com, device=vda}, 120) > 1000
When done with the Expressions Editor, click Complete Editing to close the Alarm Expression Editor form.
When done creating the alarm, click Create Alarm.

section.p: After the alarm definition saves, the Alarm Definitions window refreshes with the new alarm definition populates in the table.
